H0.text: Scientific skepticism is the practice of questioning claims based on their scientific verifiability rather than accepting claims based on faith or anecdotes.

H1.text: Scientific extreme is questioning claims based on their scientific verifiability rather than accepting claims based on faith or anecdotes.

H2.text: Scientific mimicry is questioning claims based on their scientific verifiability rather than accepting claims based on faith or anecdotes.

H3.text: Scientific fact refers to questioning claims based on their scientific verifiability rather than accepting claims based on faith or anecdotes.

A4.text: Scientific skeptics attempt to evaluate claims based on verifiability and falsifiability; they discourage accepting claims which rely on faith or anecdotal evidence.

A5.text: Scientific skepticism or rational skepticism (also spelled scepticism), sometimes referred to as skeptical inquiry, is a position in which one questions the veracity of claims lacking scientific evidence.
